choices.B: Identify the shared key by running the PowerShell cmdlet: Get -AzVirtualNetworkGatewayConnectionVpnDeviceConfigScript
choices.A: Identify the shared key by running this PowerShell cmdlet: Get-AzVirtualNetworkGatewayConnectionSharedKey.

questions.question_text:
A company configures an Azure site-to-site VPN between an on-premises network and an Azure virtual network.
The company reports that after completing the configuration, the VPN connection cannot be established.
You need to troubleshoot the connection issue.
What should you do first?

discussion.content:
The most common reason for a site-to-site VPN connection not being established is a mismatch in the pre-shared keys (shared secrets) on both ends of the connection. This is often the first thing that should be checked when a VPN connection fails to establish. 

Therefore, the correct answer should be:

A. Identify the shared key by running this PowerShell cmdlet: Get-AzVirtualNetworkGatewayConnectionSharedKey.

This cmdlet retrieves the pre-shared key for the specified Azure site-to-site VPN connection, which can then be compared with the pre-shared key configured on the on-premises VPN device to ensure they match. If the keys don't match, the VPN connection will fail to establish. 

The other options are not as relevant:

- Option B, the cmdlet Get-AzVirtualNetworkGatewayConnectionVpnDeviceConfigScript, is used to generate a configuration script for the on-premises VPN device, which is useful, but not the first step in troubleshooting.

- Options C and D refer to certificate files that are relevant in certificate-based authentication scenarios, not a pre-shared key (PSK) authentication scenario, which is typically used in site-to-site VPNs.

Selected Answer: A
A is correct.

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.network/get-azvirtualnetworkgatewayconnectionsharedkey?view=azps-9.6.0

questions.question_text:
HOTSPOT -
A company is deploying Azure Bastion to provide secure clientless access to its Azure VMs. The company configures a network security group named NSG1.
During deployment, the following error displays: Network security group NSG1 does not have necessary rules for Azure Bastion Subnet AzureBastionSubnet.
You need to fix the inbound rules for NSG1.
How should you complete the configuration? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
//IMG//

HOTSPOT -
A company attempts to implement just-in-time (JIT) access for a virtual machine (VM) named VM1.
The company reports that they are unable to complete the process.
You need to implement JIT access and test the deployment.
Which PowerShell cmdlets should you run? To answer, select the appropriate options in the answer area.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.
//IMG//

choices.A: Monitor traffic with the following PowerShell cmdlet New-AzNetworkWatcherFlowlog.
choices.D: Configure Azure Bastion with static assignment.
choices.E: Run the Network Watcher Connection troubleshoot service.
choices.C: Monitor traffic with the following PowerShell cmdlet Test-AzNetworkWatcherConnectivity.
choices.B: Apply a network security group on the same subnet as Azure Bastion.

questions.question_text:
A company deploys Azure Bastion to connect to their virtual machine (VM) infrastructure.
An engineer attempts to connect to a Windows VM by using Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP). The connection fails.
You need to troubleshoot the issue.
Which two actions should you perform? Each correct answer presents a complete solution.
NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
Given answers are correct

Seems right - basically both answer do about the same thing anyway, in a real life I would just go with the Connection Troubleshooter.

C - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/az.network/test-aznetworkwatcherconnectivity?view=azps-9.6.0

E - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/bastion/troubleshoot#connectivity

questions.question_text:
DRAG DROP -

A company uses ExpressRoute to connect an on-premises datacenter to Azure. You deploy two virtual machines (VMs) named VM1 and VM2 in Azure. You configure Internet Information Services (IIS) on VM1.

Users experience the following connection issues from on-premises:

• Unable to connect to IIS on VM1
• Latency connection issues with VM2

You need to troubleshoot the issues.

Which cmdlets should you use? To answer, drag the appropriate cmdlets to the correct target VMs. Each cmdlet may be used once, more than once, or not at all. You may need to drag the split bar between panes or scroll to view content.

NOTE: Each correct selection is worth one point.

//IMG//

discussion.content:
given answer is correct.

Get-AzureNetworkAvailability - https://github.com/Azure/NetworkMonitoring/blob/main/AzureCT/AvailabilityTesting.md#fast-start

 Get-LinkPerformance - https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/expressroute/expressroute-troubleshooting-network-performance#azurect---the-azure-connectivity-toolkit
